awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSF-DFG: CAS: Electrochemical Hydrogenation of Amides and Esters
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation Division of Chemistry, Nilay Hazari from Yale University and Alex Miller from the University of North Carolina, in collaboration with the University of Göttingen in Germany, aim to develop new methods for the preparation of chemical precursors to pharmaceuticals and polymers. The project will provide fundamental guidelines on how to use electricity in chemical synthesis, leading to more environmentally friendly routes to industrial chemicals relative to current methods that rely on toxic or environmentally damaging chemicals. Students will learn new techniques and broaden their education through an international exchange program in which graduate students from the University of Göttingen will travel to either Yale or the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, and students from the American institutions will travel to the University of Göttingen. 

The hydrogenation of carboxylic acid derivatives, such as esters and amides, represents an atom economical process for the production of synthetically valuable alcohols and amines. Recent advances in hydrogenation for amine and alcohol synthesis have relied on dihydrogen gas, which is however currently produced in an environmentally harmful process from fossil fuels. In this project, a collaborative team consisting of Nilay Hazari from Yale University and Alex Miller from the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, in further collaboration with the University of Göttingen, will use funding from the National Science Foundation Division of Chemistry to develop electrocatalysts for the reduction of esters and amides using protons and electrons. The approach will leverage detailed mechanistic studies on a recently developed manganese electrocatalyst for ketone reduction, including kinetic analysis and spectro-electrochemical detection of intermediates, to provide a basis for developing systems capable of reducing esters and amides. A particular focus will be on synthesizing key hydride intermediates and establishing their thermodynamic and kinetic hydricity. In addition to promising more sustainable synthetic methods, electrochemical hydrogenation may well emerge as a hydrogenation method that is more tolerant of functional groups, such as acidic sites, and, as such, find broad application in academia and industry.


This research was funded under the NSF-DFG Lead Agency Activity in Electrosynthesis and Electrocatalysis (NSF-DFG EChem) opportunity NSF 20-578.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop basic principles for using electricity to mediate chemical synthesis for pharmaceutical applications. The specific class of reactions studied involved the electroreduction of less reactive carboxylic acid derivatives, such as esters, to alcohols. Current methods for achieving this transformation often require high pressures of hydrogen gas and elevated temperatures, which can reduce functional group tolerance and decrease the sustainability of these reactions.

The major outcome of this project was the discovery of a manganese-based electrocatalyst for the reduction of esters. Although the catalyst currently reduces only activated esters—such as those containing fluorine atoms—to our knowledge, this work represents the first reported example of ester electroreduction. The catalyst is selective and does not produce significant quantities of hydrogen as a by-product. Moreover, it is based on a first-row transition metal and is straightforward to prepare. Future studies will explore the full substrate scope of the electrocatalytic reduction and elucidate the mechanism.

As part of this project, several new ligands and transition metal complexes were prepared. These new ligands will likely support a range of transition metal complexes beyond those specifically studied here. For instance, it should be possible to prepare iron and cobalt complexes using the new ligands. Additionally, the new complexes may prove useful in catalytic applications beyond electrocatalytic ester reduction. For example, we demonstrated that the manganese catalysts developed for ester reduction were also capable of reducing carbon dioxide. This led to the discovery of an immobilized molecular catalyst for carbon dioxide reduction to formate.

This project was a collaboration between Yale, the University of North Carolina (Professor Alex Miller’s group), and the University of Göttingen (Professor Inke Siewert’s group) in Germany. Early-career researchers involved in the project benefited from interactions with research groups that had different scientific perspectives and areas of expertise. For instance, the Miller and Siewert groups specialize in electrochemistry, while the Hazari group has greater experience in synthetic methods. This diversity of skills provided valuable professional development for the early-career researchers, broadening their education and exposing them to different scientific cultures.
